title-group.article-title: Authors’ Response to Correspondence on “Mesial Temporal Sclerosis in a Cohort of Children With SCN1A Gene Mutation”

article-meta.aff: Le Bonheur Comprehensive Epilepsy Program, Memphis, TN, USA
University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Memphis, TN, USA
St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, Memphis, TN, USA

body.p: We appreciate the commentary by Drs. Siegler and Fogarasi. We agree that it is interesting and unclear why the association between mesial temporal sclerosis and SCN1A mutation has been seen in some studies yet has been rare in others. Some of the variation could be due to study design. Our study, like other studies, 1,2 had specific focus on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abnormalities with a dedicated review of all the images by trained pediatric neuroradiologists. However, in some studies, such as the article by Korff et al, 3 MRI findings were only mentioned as part of an overall retrospective review of features of Dravet syndrome. In the future, larger studies evaluating possible associations between the patient’s spectrum of seizure activity, febrile seizures, and presence or type of genetic mutation in the SCN1A gene may help to illuminate this issue. In addition, the ongoing Consequences of Prolonged Febrile Seizures in Childhood (FEBSTAT) study looking at the relationship between febrile status epilepticus and development of mesial temporal sclerosis may also shed light on this subject. 4 In their initial findings, 3 patients were identified with Dravet syndrome, and as the study progresses others could possibly be identified. Prospective evaluation of their MRIs may provide further insight. Possible studies in the future could also include SCN1A mutation testing in young adults with mesial temporal sclerosis, because not all of our patients presented as typical Dravet syndrome.
